reviewText:
Ah, Universal Combat.  Somehow I hoped we had seen the last of Derek Smart.  Don't get me wrong, I don't despise the man, but his snarky, combative attitude in the face of the overwhelming evidence regarding his shortcomings as a developer have left me hoping for the day when he retires from public life; that, and I was one of the foolish who purchased Universal Combat when it came out only to discover it was broken and buggy even after several patches and any attempts to challenge this was met by scorn and insult by Derek Smart himself.

This is not a good game.  It will not be a good game no matter how many times he changes the name.  It IS a very ambitious game, however.  To his credit, Derek Smart tried to make a game that pushed hardware and design boundaries.  The sad reality is that he failed, but rather than accept this and work with critics to address the problems he chose to attack whatever fanbase he had for pointing out the shortcomings of the game,.  Now it is on steam (for free, no less) and that is supposed to diminish your ability to criticise this product, but for those of us who purchased the game when it first came out it just brings back visions of falling through surfaces, user interfaces better suited to spreadsheet software than a game and terrible, game destroying bugs.

I won't address the visuals, which for the time were not bad.  I bought the game originally because of the promise of fps and ship based exploration and combat, and what I ended up with were two halves that never really seemed to fit together or work even on their own.  Attempting to hold the two halves together is an interface that is poorly thought out (see how long it takes you to figure out how quit for a start) and overcomplicated with fields and windows of redundant settings best handled with a single button or accessible from a quick bar.

It's unfortunate (but not surprising) to see that time has not changed Derek at all; looking at the comments on steam he continues to attack naysayers with the same eagerness he did on his own forums once, and that is a shame.  I would have hoped that the years had brought him some wisdom about dealing with critics and fans alike, and that rather than insult their intelligence and rebuff their concerns with snarky comments he would have hired a PR representative who has less of an irrational response to criticism.

You will likely play Universal Combat regardless of my review, and I invite you to do so.  You will also discover that the game has some nebulous design decisions and unresolved bugs that will hamper your enjoyment.  Just do not expect your feedback or criticism to be well received or heeded at all by the game's designer as he has great difficulty accepting flaws in his work, though he will gladly take all of your praise.

reviewText:
So.....this game.

Putting aside any personal isssues with Derek Smart (and let's be honest, a lot of people have issues with him), let's try to be as objective as possible in this review...

What exactly is UC and does it live up to its claims?


It's a 'do anything in space' simulator. You want to command a battlecruiser? Check. You want to be a Marine on a planet shooting stuff? Check. You want to fly from a planet to space and dock with that carrier you see over there? Check.

The problem is...well....the problems are...

One: Excessive micro management: Why for instance, should the commander of a large ship have to manually set power levels? Why can't....say....the crrew AI do that for you and if you want to then alter it, you can? By default, there isnt't enough power to go around and you have to go in and manually set it. Or, say you want to send....I don't know, four Marines and a tank and a pilot to a planet. You have to tell each individual what to do. There's no group option.

Two: HUD issues. The HUD itself isn't intuitive at all, the three MFDs at the bottom of the screen don't easily tell you what they are, the radar is 2d, not 3D and that is confusing as well as you got no clue if the enemy target is above or blow you.

Three: Questionable vehicle physics. Why should a shuttle be able to stop on a dime in space? I can understand tanks or ATVs stopping quickly on a planet, that makes sense, however...a shuttle, in space, you cut the power and it instantly stops? Really? Yes, I'm aware it's explained away as some technical stuff but that's an easy and cheap way to get around the issue.

So what are the good points then given I've laid out some issues with it?

One: You can literally go anywhere and do anything you want to. For instance in a free roaming scenario, I have taken a battlecruiser from Ear to the Moon, landed troops, done exercises, got picked up by the shuttle and flown back, all without cutscenes or scripting.

Two: It's seamless once it loads. Yep that's a big, big plus. You want to go from planet to space? Get above a certain height and push a button, then confirm it (again....micro management issues but....), there's a few seconds worth of animation and you're in space. Same for going to a planet.s, get close, it'll ask establish planetfall, say yes,a nd sit back.

It's pretty. Oh yes it is, it's some of the most atmospheric graphics in a space game....and you feel as if you can actually go to that nebula, or that planet....or even that base and dock there

You are not the hero. Okay, this is  astrange one but....most games are all about the player, right? Well, UC, CE isn't. There's an entire universe going on, things happen regardless of you being around or not. You can be in a system and go off for a few days, come back and find that station you were docked at got attacked and changed hands, or there's a war on a planet that broke out while you were going there.

However....I personally wouldn't recommend it unless you want to spend a LOT of time reading and learning. It's not a simple pick up and play game in the least, it takes time, dedication and (sadly) figuring things out on your own so you don't have to deal with Derek Smart to enjoy it. Don't get me wrong, once you like it, it's definitely good but I do feel many, many people will be put off by Derek Smart and won't even look at it.

If UC was made by somebody else and released on Steam for free, it would get a much, much better reception, I can absolutely say that for certain.

Either way, although this has not recommended at  the top, try try it out. Make up your own mind and be prepared for a lot of reading and learning too.

reviewText:
IMPORTANT TIP

If you jump into this game without reading the manual (you roguish maniac you!) and you’re stuck press either Ctrl+H, Alt+H or Shift+H which will both pause the game and call up the manual or control bindings.
Press Ctrl+H to exit the documents.

Well…I usually don’t bother writing Steam reviews as I often trust in the overall consensus of those that have already done so (what difference would my 2 cents make?).
However this is probably the first time I have found myself in a situation where a game I hold in high regard is otherwise very divided in opinion.

I suppose this is the very essence of what it is to be a “niche” game so the first thing I should probably say in this review is that “Universal Combat” (UC) is not for everyone.
You will come out of it either loving it or hating it, but very unlikely anything in between.

Now much has been said about the need to read the manual before playing and I can appreciate that many gamers nowadays (particularly the younger generation) would consider this requirement (at best) rather quaint in 2015.
Indeed with there being so many free games and demos right there at your fingertips, I can see how the investment of time would be a deal breaker for some.
As such the best I can do is tell you what 3 aspects of UC appeal to me the most, and should you be intrigued, perhaps you might be willing to preserver though the trials of learning how to play it.

* Scale:
The 3D environments for both space and planet side are mind-bogglingly vast and I am not aware of any other space sim that can match it (at least outside of an MMO).

Capital ships dwarf the size of their occupants (you’ll notice this if you decided to go on a space walk outside your ship) and these ships in turn are tiny compared to the celestial scale of the planets & moons within this universe.
If find that UC conveys the enormity of space exceptionally well.
It is a very humbling experience to fly to a plant and watch as it fills up the entirety of the view screen.

*Planetary landings:
Like the space environment, the planet surface is massive (it takes 5 hours in real time to fly around the Earth in a shuttle) and they all have a day/night cycle (some even have weather effects).
But what really sets this apart from every other space sim I’ve known is that it lets you land on any moon or planet you come across and explore it in first person (even a gas giant if you don’t mind dying).
Any on top of that you can land anywhere you like on the planet’s surface rather than being restricted to predefined zones.
However I will admit that the price for this vastness is a great deal of emptiness as the areas outside the city & base zones are pretty much uninhabited.
Nevertheless I feel that the procedural generation works well mixing up the terrain features so it’s not like the surface is uniform and everywhere looks the same (the exception of course being barren moonscapes which are supposed to look samey).

* A.I
I’m the kind of guy that is fascinated by A.I in gaming.
I find it as much fun observing what an A.I does in various situations as I do playing the game.
And Universal Combat has a pretty interesting A.I to observe.

Even as you go about your business in the game there is a hell of a lot going on behind the scenes.
Trade ships are randomly generated which proceed to each star station along a route buying & selling goods. This will affect the inventory a station has to sell as well as the economy in general.
Next you have raiders which are also randomly generated.
They will try to attack the aforementioned trade ships and thus their success/failure also affects inventory & economy of the stations.
You have :
- Criminals being generated, with police being generated to pursue them.
- Diplomats appearing and assassins dispatched to attack them.
- Colonists & workers headed to uninhabited planets to build cities
- Paramedics looking for the distress signals
And of course rival military forces clashing in as chance encounters or as retaliation for some other transgression for which the player never witnessed.

While you're docked in a station getting repairs a whole dammed war could be going on outside and given enough time nations that were allies in the beginning of the game can sometimes become enemies just by one incident that the player may have nothing to do with.

*Overall:
To me Universal Combat is something very special: A vast simulation experiment with a game thrown in.

I have been watching this game’s predecessor (the Battlecruiser series) since 1998 and in all that time I have seen nothing which comes close to it in terms of scope & scale.
UC is a vast improvement on the old Battlecruiser series in every conceivable way and yet here it is being offered for FREE!?...Unbelievable.

However as I said before it is not for everyone.

reviewText:
Here are my thoughts about this game.

As a fan of this series , i am really excited about beeing able to play this game again.

This game is a space battleship simulator. Although you can play as a marine/fighter pilot/merchand/insurgent/...   the main focus of this game is to be in command of a big space carrier. And in this aspect it is brilliant. The games gives you the option of micromanaging every aspect of your ship, for example the traditional power distribution, but also shield strenght, weapons management, crew managent, control of your fighter squadron, the ability to send shuttles with marines to board enemy ships. The possibilities are endless.
There is a huge galaxy with planets and moons you can land on, bases to dock or destroy. You can mine ressources, trade, or just blow up ships. Either in free roam, or in a sort of campaign.
But so is the complexity of this game: Fighters need rearming and refuelling, crew needs to be assigned to pre-flight the fighters, your crew needs rest, it takes time to get them through the ship, If your damaged, ship systems must be repaired, these systems need various ressources and time to be repaired. Most of these functions will be done automatically, but you still need to check everything in a while.
As a result, the gameplay is slow. Engagements may take some time, sometimes your vital repairs need 30 minutes or more, your fighters won't be ready for the next 15 minutes.
And the learning curve for this game is steep. The tutorial is not really all that helpful, the UI is complex and difficult to understand, and understanding this game is going to take a while.
The graphics are vary old, and can best be described as functional, but ugly. I experienced some crashes and some laggy UI in the crew management screen.

So, should you play this game?
If you are looking for some instant action, fast space dogfights or FPS action, then don't download it. Also, if you expect some sort of interesting campaign, you will be dissapointed. As this campaign only provides some missions via text messages.

But if you are looking for a great space carrier simulator, which gives you total freedom, a universe that reacts to your actions, and a really detailed and comlex ship systems, this game is for you. If won't be annoyed by old graphics, are able to form your own campaign in your mind, and are willing to invest a couple of hours to really learn the game before you even start to play it, then you will have some great ours of fun.

If you are not sure about it, then just try it, it's for free, but be aware that is is really difficult to get into.

reviewText:
(I've played this game long before it came on steam, hence the very low playtime on record)

I'd love to recommend this game. I really would. I actually really enjoy it. I can't, though. I think there's something to be said about the hivemind downrating the living hell out of this game. It really boils down to poor explanation and implementation.

The idea behind the game is fantastic, moreso that Smart actually more or less accomplished the scope of the game. Its the ultimate space adventure - command a super carrier complete with awesome offensive weaponry, crew, fighter pilots, and marines. Launch invasions of planetary bases from orbit, or make planetfall and glass the damn thing yourself.

When you get to the knitty gritty, though, that's what things start to fall apart. How the hell do I fly this thing? Alright, lemme dig up this 99 page manual... which, lets be real - I love a game with depth but I'm not in school and I'm not here to read a fat-♥♥♥ manual. Not everybody is like me, either, and won't spend hours of frustration learning it the 'fun' way. They'll just give up, instead. Which they do. I think a proper tutorial would go a long way to explaining to the player what they need to know.

The controls feel awfully stiff, too. Spacecraft don't really fly like spacecraft... or aircraft, for that matter. Rolling in atmosphere doesn't change your heading at all, and your yaw authority is waaay higher than it should. Add in a fudged up sense of scale (good luck hitting something moving that fast) and atmospheric combat is nigh impossible except between capital ships.

I won't even get into the ground combat. It certainly has it. What little I've experienced of it is enough for me to know I can't review it without sounding scathing.

Its a shame. I want to give this a thumbs up. I've actually had fun learning how to play it, and if it were just the learning curve I'd say don't be a ♥♥♥♥♥ and go right in. Sadly, its more than that, and for that I have to give Smart a failing grade.

reviewText:
The best spaceSHIP simulator I know of.

Yeah, I played Freespace and X series, not to mention Wing Commander (Privateer spinoff).  They all are fine but there you always command what is effectively a fighter.  And if you came to UC with the same assumption you will, you were, sorely disappointed.

The UC is not for everyone.  First off, you *have* to Read That F*ing Manual, period.  Otherwise you will not know not just how to do what you are supposed to do, but even what you are supposed to do in first place.  And you are supposed to no less than to take care of your SHIP, a spaceship.  With her crew, equipment, armament, subsystems and so on, all while cruising through the emptiness of space.  It's not like it's SpaceCimCity.  It's more like being in shoes of Captains Kirk, Picard or Janeway.  The level of micromanagement is overwhelming at the beginning but in time I found it lands in my personal sweet spot where it is enough of it to keep the game engaging and not enough of it to be bogged down.

If you prefer quick fast paced action you may want to stay away from this game, that's fine.  Though if you want to have the feeling of being actual captain, give it a chance despite the learning curve.  Besides, every skip' had to learn his ropes, and it always took time.

P.S. I have clocked so little here just because nowdays I don't have that much time to play this game.  But I had spent my deal playing earlier versions starting from BC3K, through BCM and ending on non-Steam UC.  I wish I could play it more but alas, priorioties and obligations IRL.

I bought the DLC with the added fixes and campaigns, but this applies to the free version as well since they are fairly similar (well for the moment).

I used to play Battlecruiser Millennium a few years ago yet I still needed to refresh my memory - the interface and controls are not intuitive, but after reading the manual and tutorial, and playing for a few hours, they become functional. Once past that stage, the game can be truly appreciated for its massive scope and the freedom it gives the player as a captain of a huge spaceship. The sense of scale is exceptional  - I sometimes land my 1 km carrier at a planet only to go outside and walk besides it, or go for an EVA near a huge star station and zoom out. This is awesome stuff  (yes even if the first person mode is less than stellar. But then this is mostly a space sim and a unique one at that).

I must say I actually find this game pretty. It is dated, but the lighting, textures and models are very nice and atmospheric (see my screenshots). The design of the ships looks realistic with visible launch bays, bridge, etc. Being mostly a hard core flight simmer I like these small touches.

In the Captain career, being able to manage the crew, the ships resources and smaller crafts (fighters and shuttles) appeals to me a lot and I don't think it can be done at this level in other games. There is plenty of stuff to do in the huge galaxy in roam mode - trading, space combat, mining, planet ops...

I can also say stability has improved since the initial Steam release and it is not an issue anymore. And I have been playing quite a lot lately.

If you like space sims and aren't afraid complex games ignore the bashing and give it a try. Truly highly recommended.

(PS I'm looking forward to the added features of the DLC, especially the 3D bridge - that sounds like a blast).

reviewText:
An underrated indie gem. Derek Smart deserves credit for sticking to his guns, and sticking with this game. Universal Combat isn't pretty, easy or intuitive. But it's still an unmatched capital ship simulator with an unforgiving '90s-style attitude.

This game will not hold your hand (tip: read the manual) or tuck you into bed at night. It's definitely not for everybody. It's about outer space and it wants to kill you. It's a sandbox with the complexity of hardcore naval sims such as Silent Hunter.

It's about logistics, space battles, crew management, reactor meltdowns and nuking cities from orbit. You will be boarded, ransacked and the perpetrators will escape in a stolen shuttlecraft.

Your ship will be set adrift while on fire.

Why Universal Combat Matters
I didn't discover this game until recently. I've known about Smart since the early 2000s, but dismissed him and didn't give him a chance. He was a joke, a crank, his games were bad. That's what I thought, but in reality I didn't understand him.

Now I do ... I think.

Smart is foremost an engineer, as this game reflects an engineer's mindset. It's about spaceships, but it's really about complex systems, taking things apart and figuring out how they work. This has its downsides: Engineers are not celebrated for their empathy and they don't make for great artists.

But engineers do make great systems.

reviewText:
It's 02:38 and we are four jumps deep in to Gammulan space. Already we have taken out two enemy cargo ships and an insurgent light cruiser. But when we ran up against an Engstrom, it was all our Warhammer could do to hold off their fighters and get past their laser system to catch up and make the kill.

We have damage on all decks, intruders on board, and a third of our marines are dead with more headed to sick bay. We are attempting to land on a moon for repairs and to lay low for a bit. Don't worry; we'll be back.

Universal Combat is something of a trip in to the past, and anyone playing it needs to realize that. When I first played this way-back-when, it was probably the most absolutely complicated game I had ever attempted to play, and 14-year-old me really liked having to figure everything out as I went along and really learn how to play this thing. And frankly, that's where the satisfaction is. Universal Combat hails from a time when games really didn't tell you how good you were doing. There were no 'atta-boys. The satisfaction came from realizing that you had figured the game out and were getting good at it.

I suggest giving this a try and playing it for at least 6 hours before deciding if you like it or not. I personally enjoy the challenge of not just moment-to-moment ship management, but of the long term planning you can really get in to when determining either a brief patrol of border space or an extended campaign in to enemy territory. What spare parts should I take? Where should I deploy mining drones for resupply? Where can I park for repairs? And I do mean park for repairs; if you make poor choices and take damage, you realistically could be down for hours. It's brutal. But coming through several of those limp-home-and-pray adventures is what builds the narrative in your head and really helps you get in to the game, I think. I might not be able to follow my marine security detail around while they hunt down saboteurs, but damn if I don't stare at the PERSCAN screen and yell obscenities at them anyways.

It's not polished, it's not perfect. You'll have complaints. But if you give it a real chance and keep an open mind, you'll probably never forget playing it, and you'll have a totally different sort of fun with it than you do with Planetside 2 or Smite. And hopefully you'll stick around for Derek's next project, because I have a feeling it should be pretty cool.

Let's get this out right now, this game is complex, definitely NOT for the casual space shooter fan. You may see reviews on here saying there is no tutorial, well there is a tutorial free roam scenario designed to be played along with a written tutorial document included. This is a game from the days when you had to read a whacking great manual and tackle a learning curve that was very steep. Once it is learned, however, it opens up a whole galaxy to explore and a myriad of options and things to do. Want to fly around the galaxy looking for a fight? It's here. Want to land troops on a planet with tanks and fighter planes to assault an enemy stronghold? That's here too. Want to take control of those vehicles on the planet surface and get stuck in yourself? Yep you can! You can even land your huge capital ship on any planet/moon and get out for a stroll around taking in the sights. There's trading and mining here as well as salvage from destroyed ships, towing ships in distress to a star station for help, real time movement of crew around the ship, full control of power distribution to all systems on your ship, teleporter to transport men/cargo down to a planet surface, and evac them from the planet and so much more.

This game has it all from capital ship command to slugging it out on planets or even the hull of your ship in first person mode, naval vessels and space fighters which can also be flown in the planet's atmosphere to support your ground troops.

All this from an indie dev team in the early noughties! The version here on Steam is an overhauled and remastered version of the original 2009 Collectors Edition and to have it here for free is nothing short of amazing. What have you got to lose? Download it now, you won't regret it!!

I play this series since the Battlecruiser Millenium, and love it!

I did not play much of this particular release yet, so I cannot say how stable it is. It does not support Alt-Tab, and windowed mode is available but not really supported.

UPDATE 11 hours in: The game is very stable. Crashed only once and I could not replicate conditions.

As for the game, it is not self contained, meaning that you must read the manual and possibly do the tutorial. This game is an acquired taste and involves a lot of knowledge and study.

This game is not really about you dogfighting, even if you can take a planetary defense fighter and pilot it. The meat of the game is the capital ship. Crew management (it simulates where each crew member is and what they are doing, even if you can't walk inside the ship) and other internal management of a capital ship, including a fighter squadron. You can be boarded, coordinate ground operations, pilot shuttles or fighters of your carrier, use orbital missiles, take over enemy space stations and explore a universe that, while not as large as Elite: Dangerous, will take you a long time to explore.

Multiple races and occupations will change the game dynamic. There are military carriers, science vessels, trade ships, small fighters and more!

As for the Campaign, I never had much interest in it. I rather take a Battlecruiser MK3 and roam around the universe with a reduced risk of court martial.

I always had a lot of fun with this game. Maybe this is the one game that inspired me to become a game developer, even if not the best game I ever played. I understand it is not for everyone, but it was for me and I must recommend.

reviewText:
I really like this game and highly recommend it to anyone who likes old school PC games and simulations. If you ever dreamed of being in command of a space battleship then you should give this game a try. I spent many nights flying through the galaxy role playing as Captain Julian Augustus, Battlecruiser Commander and I can't wait to get a free weekend or three to give it another go.

This game is very complex and and takes a while to learn to play it. This game is originally from a time when PC games came in a box and included a detailed and lengthy manual. These manuals were often a treat and included background information, cool artwork, a written tutorial, list of commands, etc. I miss those types of manuals.

The tutorial is a PDF file that you print out or read on a tablet while you play through the tutorial scenarios.  I'd recommend doing that. And print out the command reference as well or keep it open on a tablet.

The main thing to understand is that this game is deliberately complex. It is designed for someone who wants to feel like they are commanding a real battleship. To get the most out of this game you have to learn to play it and you have to use your imagination and really get into the role playing and the simulation. If you treat it like an arcade style game you're going to get frustrated.
